dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A cold winter day. Jack and Clyde in separate limos point in different directions parked side by side near the exit the lot. In background, Classic office. Clyde, Jack’s fri and coworker, is well groomed, and wears a black limo sui a little better kept suit than Jack’s. Clyde passes a lit joint from out his window to his friend. A reggae song, Rivers of Babylon, is heard playing in Jack’s limo on an style tape portable player.

dialogues.speaker: CLYDE
dialogues.text: You thought about it?

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: (mervous throat clearing) A-hem...

dialogues.speaker: CLYDE
dialogues.text: (after a pause) «+I think you should.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: What's she do there?

dialogues.speaker: CLYDE
dialogues.text: She’s the assistant to the embalmer.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Aw, no...

dialogues.speaker: CLYDE
dialogues.text: ..+.something with the fluids.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: No, aw....

dialogues.speaker: CLYDE
dialogues.text: No, man. Lucy's training her to sell seminars for Dr. Bob.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Phone sales?

dialogues.speaker: CLYDE
dialogues.text: He does seminars for the funeral directors.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: I thought he was just an undertaker. Jack passes the joint back through his car window to Clyd who takes a final toke and discards the ends.

dialogues.speaker: CLYDE
dialogues.text: She calls the funeral directors. Phone sales.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Cool. What's her name?

dialogues.speaker: CLYDE
dialogues.text: Connie. So, I‘1l tell Lucy it’s on. Jack sees a man, his uncle Frank, emerge from the office Classic and head their way.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: (indicates Uncle Frank) Here’s my Uncle. Don't mention it --

dialogues.speaker: CLYDE
dialogues.text: Hey.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: That it's...y'know... because...

dialogues.speaker: CLYDE
dialogues.text: I won't.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: He won't let it rest.

dialogues.speaker: CLYDE
dialogues.text: Not a word.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: It's how he is... Uncle Frank appears outside of Jack’s car window. He give the men a small wave and a knowing look.

dialogues.speaker: UNCLE FRANK
dialogues.text: Gentlemen. You two talking about me?

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: CLYDE
dialogues.text: Only about the money we make you.

dialogues.speaker: UNCLE FRANK
dialogues.text: That’s allowed. Your lips to God’s ears. He turns and walks back toward the Classic office. Jack turns up the volume on Rivers of Babylon. Listens with serious appreciation. Jack detects a warble in the tape.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: The tape's getting stretched.

dialogues.speaker: CLYDE
dialogues.text: You should go CD.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Probably.

dialogues.speaker: CLYDE
dialogues.text: Go high tech.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Yeah. Clyde observes Jack mouthing the words.

dialogues.speaker: CLYDE
dialogues.text: Jack. Turn it down a minute. Jack turns it down.

dialogues.speaker: CLYDE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Would you call yourself a rasta man?

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: CLYDE
dialogues.text: You thinking of becoming one?

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clyde drives off. Jack listens to the song a moment, driv away. 1/28/09 (3)

dialogues.speaker: CLYDE
dialogues.text: I just wanted to ask.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: You like the song? Reggae's mainly positive.

dialogues.speaker: CLYDE
dialogues.text: Some of the words, you know, I don't get, so it's hard to commit.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: "Over I" is a hard one.

dialogues.speaker: CLYDE
dialogues.text: “Over I?"

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: "Over I," yeah.

dialogues.speaker: CLYDE
dialogues.text: We'll just order something and hang out.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: CLYDE
dialogues.text: No biggie.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: INT/EXT. JACK’S LIMO - DAY Jack drives. Italian woman in rear. Boxes and bags of purchases. The Italian woman is on her cell phone, talkin Italian. Her short talk is punctuated by the names of hig end clothing stores, Barneys, etc. She hangs up, with kis After a moment--

dialogues.speaker: ITALIAN WOMAN
dialogues.text: You drive long time?

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: ITALIAN WOMAN
dialogues.text: You married? + eH

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: ITALIAN WOMAN
dialogues.text: I practice my English. Sorry.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: That’s OK.

dialogues.speaker: ITALIAN WOMAN
dialogues.text: I love New York. People are nice. In Rome. Awful. Rude.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack stands at the opened door as the Italian woman puts packages into the limo.

dialogues.speaker: ITALIAN WOMAN
dialogues.text: “Dressing for success.” That's right?

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Yes, ma’am. Dress for success.

dialogues.speaker: ITALIAN WOMAN
dialogues.text: Dress for success. Maybe shoes now. She climbs into the limo.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A valet drives away the car of a newly arrived couple, wh carry gift wrapped packages. Immediately following, anoth car pulls up, and behind it, Clyde’s limo is in line, rea to deliver his passengers.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: INT. CLYDE’S LIMO - NIGHT 6 Clyde eyes the happy couple in the back seat from the van of the rear view mirror. A young daughter of five between them. She has an extravagantly wrapped present on her lap and is playing with the bow.

dialogues.speaker: DADDY
dialogues.text: Leave the pretty bow alone, sweetie.

dialogues.speaker: MOMMY
dialogues.text: You heard Daddy, honey, we want it pretty like you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clyde pulls the car up to the valet station. He gets out opens the door for the happy family. They exit the car an enter the hotel.

dialogues.speaker: CLYDE
dialogues.text: (to Valet) Can I get a minute, I got to run to the men’s room?

dialogues.speaker: VALET
dialogues.text: Pull it out of the way. And don’t be all day.

dialogues.speaker: CLYDE
dialogues.text: Thanks. He hustles into the limo to pull it out of the way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An attendant stands by the opulent wash basins. Clyde finishes at a urinal and moves to wash his hands. The attendant offers Clyde a squeeze of a French hand soap fr fancy looking bottle. Clyde washes his hands. The attenda smiles and readies a towel. Clyde dries his hands. After another moment of the two men looking at one another, mor less expressionless, Clyde takes some change out of his pocket.

dialogues.speaker: ATTENDANT
dialogues.text: No coins. The attendant steps back. Clyde puts a buck in a tip bowl exits.

dialogues.speaker: SECOND LOBBY, WALDORF ASTORIA
dialogues.text: Clyde looks into and enters busy second lobby. He notices busboys/pastry assistants going into Empire Room. Clyde follows them.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: s

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clyde looks in at the room catered for a wedding receptio Gifts. Guests, including the couple and child he drove wh are at a table picking up id name tags, (”“Hi, I’m Nonnie Plimpton”.) Clyde enters the lobby. A small gathering of well-dressed arrivals for the event sip cocktails and cha with each other near a pianist playing appropriate music. trolley of desserts passes Clyde. Guests part to make way it. A very tall pastry chef in white is revealed giving directions on the placement of the desserts. Clyde observ the man. After a moment, young woman with a guest list approaches Clyde. Her smile hides her obvious opinion tha Clyde doesn’t belong.

dialogues.speaker: EVENT ASSISTANT
dialogues.text: May I help you?

dialogues.speaker: CLYDE
dialogues.text: No. No. Clyde heads for the exit.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: INT. DR. BOB’S MORTUARY BASEMENT AREA — DAY 13 Connie is on a phone at a work space studying with nervou intensity a form of instructions titled, “Overcoming Objections.”

dialogues.speaker: CONNIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Hi. I’m calling from Dr. Bob’s Grief Seminars. Dr. Bob’s. Yes. Is this Mr. Pendecker? Did you get Dr. Bob’s flyer on the upcoming seminar in Phoenix? Uh-huh. Uh-huh.

dialogues.speaker: BASEMENT
dialogues.text: Lucy, around Connie’s age, and her immediate boss, walks two phone sale workers at their separate work stations th are making calls and giving pitches for Dr. Bob’s seminar/workshop services to other funeral directors acro the nation. She gives one a thumbs up as she takes a confirmation slip from her and moves on by --

dialogues.speaker: LUCY
dialogues.text: Someone's getting the bonus. Lucy walks to the open office door to Dr. Bob’s office. D Bob dips into view as he gives Lucy a quick congratulator hug. At the same time, he looks over at Connie, strugglin the phone.

dialogues.speaker: DR BOB
dialogues.text: What’s the verdict?

dialogues.speaker: LUCY
dialogues.text: The jury’s still out. Lucy turns and crosses to Connie’s work area.

dialogues.speaker: CONNIE
dialogues.text: Well, Dr. Bob's not here, right this minute, but I...

dialogues.speaker: LUCY
dialogues.text: (quietly emphatic) Credit Card.

dialogues.speaker: CONNIE
dialogues.text: The new seminar experience offers techniques-- that’s right-- “violent acts... The pain of sudden deaths--” I did?

dialogues.speaker: LUCY
dialogues.text: Credit Card.

dialogues.speaker: CONNIE
dialogues.text: Oh, ah-- Mr. Pendecker? (to Lucy) He said to call back tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: LUCY
dialogues.text: Remember, it’s “Hello, the opening, gimme the credit card, the pitch, blah blah, gimme the credit card...” it’s a mantra...  14 15 16 17

dialogues.speaker: CONNIE
dialogues.text: (repeats it quietly) Gimme the credit card.

dialogues.speaker: LUCY
dialogues.text: They want you to give them permission to invest in themselves. Dr. Bob appears, places a hand of reassurance on Connie’s shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: DR BOB
dialogues.text: Another peek at the website might help with the calls. Get you familiar with what we do. (moving on) Night, night. Dr. Bob heads out and down the hall to leave the mortuary

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: INT. DR. BOB’S OFFICE, BASEMENT AREA - DAY 15 Connie is watching the Dr. Bob website on a computer. The office is decorated with Dr. Bob’s prominent memberships various national councils related to his profession, degr certificates, etc. Family pictures on his desk.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: INT. DR. BOB’S MORTUARY BASEMENT AREA 16 Lucy’s just outside the office tending to some final paperwork.

dialogues.speaker: LUCY
dialogues.text: Jack’s a sweetheart. We’ve known him a long time. You like Chinese?

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: INT. DR. BOB’S OFFICE, BASEMENT AREA 17 Connie is not sure what she’s heard.

dialogues.speaker: CONNIE
dialogues.text: He’s Chinese? I think. I’ve not known many, but...

dialogues.speaker: LUCY
dialogues.text: We'll just order some.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Website headings: Journey Through Grief-- Life and Loss - appear and dissolve on the screen in a stylish manner, followed by site choices: “Estate Planning, Cremation Workshop, Grief Certification...” Connie hits one of the headings “A message from Dr. Bob,” and an image of Dr. Bo comes on in a bucolic setting.

dialogues.speaker: DR BOB
dialogues.text: Hi, I’m Bob Thomas. My great grandfather started as a cabinet maker and undertaker in the small town of Pacerville, Oregon in 1885--

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: INT. DR. BOB’S MORTUARY BASEMENT AREA - DAY 18 Lucy is shutting down the area in preparation to leave. F inside Dr Bob’s office the “A Message from Dr. Bob” is he continuing.

dialogues.speaker: DR BOB, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: For three generations Thomas Mortuaries have lovingly cared for the needs of family, and of loved ones, in short-- service -- a tradition for one hundred twenty- five years...offering a supporting hand under life’s final transition. Bob Thomas Mortuary is a humble partner in helping you see to all your needs in affordable and complete funeral service.

dialogues.speaker: LUCY
dialogues.text: Time to get out of here.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: INT. DR. BOB’S OFFICE - DAY 19 Lucy enters.

dialogues.speaker: LUCY
dialogues.text: Tonight will be low-key. I think you'll like Jack. Connie signs off. Dr. Bob’s screen saver pops on.
INT. JACK’S BASEMENT APT — EVENING 20 Jack looks through his mess of a wardrobe for something t wear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack looks at clothes displayed outside the store. Boxes shoes, socks, underwear, undershirts; racks of pants, shi etc.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Dress for success. He walks down the block to another, more upgrade men’s clothing store. He looks at men’s clothes in the window before entering the store.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: INT. CONNIE’S STUDIO APT - EVENING 24 She sits on the bed. The clothes from cleaners, in a plas bag, across her lap. She gets up, takes a dress from the wrapped clothes and puts it on. She looks at herself ina tall, skinny, cheap mirror that leans against the wall. 9 red sticker still on the frame.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: INT. SMALL DINING AREA, CLYDE AND LUCY’S APT - NIGHT 25 Jack and Connie at the table. Remnants of Chinese food. A uncomfortable silence. Clyde enters from kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, y'know... to see your Dad like that...

dialogues.speaker: CLYDE
dialogues.text: Yeah... In a coma, man.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Clyde takes a couple plates into the kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: ... after not seeing him for a while... then...

dialogues.speaker: CONNIE
dialogues.text: The coma nurse said when he gasped for air his body did it ina reactive mode. Clyde returns relighting a joint.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Aw, that's... (to Clyde) ...right?

dialogues.speaker: CLYDE
dialogues.text: Yeah...

dialogues.speaker: CONNIE
dialogues.text: Like a dry pump. That's how he put it. I was glad when he left, and I was alone with my dad.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: ...ahem...hem...that's good, that he left... because...

dialogues.speaker: CLYDE
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: CONNIE
dialogues.text: I was glad he left.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: CONNIE
dialogues.text: He was coming on to me.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: The coma nurse?

dialogues.speaker: CLYDE
dialogues.text: Right there?

dialogues.speaker: CONNIE
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Right there in the coma room?  25 26 27

dialogues.speaker: CLYDE
dialogues.text: That's not right.

dialogues.speaker: CONNIE
dialogues.text: He let his hand stay on my arm without saying anything until my dad gasped. Then he left the coma room. My dad was right there. In a coma, but still...

dialogues.speaker: CLYDE
dialogues.text: That's not right.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: No, in the coma room with your dad right there...? In a coma, yeah, but still... Clyde passes the joint to Connie.

dialogues.speaker: CONNIE
dialogues.text: I’m fine. Jack takes it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lucy is digging through the ice cream freezer.

dialogues.speaker: LUCY
dialogues.text: No Chunky Monkey?

dialogues.speaker: DELI WORKER
dialogues.text: No. No Chunky Monkey. She exits deli.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: INT. SMALL DINING AREA, CLYDE AND LUCY’S APT - NIGHT 27 Clyde offers joint to Connie. She hesitates, takes the jo from Jack, does a small toke. Gives it to Clyde. After a moment——

dialogues.speaker: CLYDE
dialogues.text: Just getting your head around that...

dialogues.speaker: CONNIE
dialogues.text: My dad would gasp and twist his body, y'know, I thought, he wanted to get out of there. So, when I was alone with my dad, I told him it's OK to go, that he didn't have to stick around. I told him I loved him, and that he was a great dad, that he was free to go to heaven.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Yeah...

dialogues.speaker: CONNIE
dialogues.text: Two days later, he woke up out of the coma.

dialogues.speaker: CLYDE
dialogues.text: Fuck.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: That's... wow... woke up?

dialogues.speaker: CONNIE
dialogues.text: ... after three months.

dialogues.speaker: CLYDE
dialogues.text: Fuck. Clyde passes the joint. Connie takes it, starts to pass i on, does another small hit, passes it to Jack.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lucy digs through the freezer of another deli, finds and lifts a carton of Chunky Monkey up.

dialogues.speaker: LUCY
dialogues.text: Yes! Goes to counter.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: INT. SMALL DINING AREA, CLYDE AND LUCY’S APT - NIGHT 29 Connie shakes “no” to the tiny end of a joint offered by Jack, who puts it down in the ashtray.  29

dialogues.speaker: CONNIE
dialogues.text: He talked in a soft voice... like... y'know... I thought he's in like a zombie state. Not like Dawn of the Dead, but a zombie state where you stay around because there's some unfinished business you're responsible for-- like taking care of my mom.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Yeah, your mom, of course...

dialogues.speaker: CONNIE
dialogues.text: He went back to be with her at Sunshine Valley Care Facility.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: God, that's... got up from a coma and went home.

dialogues.speaker: CONNIE
dialogues.text: They were married fifty-two years.

dialogues.speaker: CLYDE
dialogues.text: Fifty-two? Unbelievable... I mean, I believe it, but, wow, fifty-two years.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: ...yeah, to make sure she was...

dialogues.speaker: CONNIE
dialogues.text: Then he fell down in the hallway and hit his head, and then he died.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: God...oh... after waking up... a kind of...

dialogues.speaker: CLYDE
dialogues.text: Yeah... a miracle coming from a coma, and then...

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: .-.cuz he wanted to take care of your mom. + eH  29 30 31

dialogues.speaker: CONNIE
dialogues.text: She was blind. She couldn't walk, really. She saw things in the air near the end. She was blind but she'd look in the air like she was seeing them. I don't know what, y'know... I asked if she was afraid to die and she said, no, but that she'd rather not. The bathroom's back there?

dialogues.speaker: CLYDE
dialogues.text: Yeah. Connie heads to the bathroom. Jack motions for Clyde to follow him to the front room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Connie breathes as though to stem an oncoming panic attac

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack and Clyde talk so Connie can’t hear them.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: I thought, ask about her parents, y'know, make conversation.

dialogues.speaker: CLYDE
dialogues.text: She needed to talk about it, I guess.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Yeah...

dialogues.speaker: CLYDE
dialogues.text: Lucy’s gone awhile, right? They probably didn't have Chunky Monkey so she's on a search. Buzzer.

dialogues.speaker: CLYDE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Huh? Huh? How many times you think, "Hey, y'know, they been gone a long time," then, buzz, y'know, they're there.  1/28/09

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: CLYDE
dialogues.text: It's hard to explain.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: I don't think you can.

dialogues.speaker: CLYDE
dialogues.text: Good point. Buzzer.

dialogues.speaker: CLYDE
dialogues.text: (into intercom) Yo! Who is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lucy’s at the intercom.

dialogues.speaker: LUCY
dialogues.text: Yo! Me.

dialogues.speaker: CLYDE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: “Me” I never forget my keys me?

dialogues.speaker: LUCY
dialogues.text: No. Buzz me fucking in me. Door buzzes and she pushes in.

dialogues.speaker: INT. FRONT ROOM- NIGHT
dialogues.text: Clyde's at the opened apt door.

dialogues.speaker: CLYDE
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Nothing.

dialogues.speaker: CLYDE
dialogues.text: It’s a game.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Connie stands in the bathroom at the mirror, distraught, tears.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lucy enters the apt and holds up deli bag.

dialogues.speaker: LUCY
dialogues.text: Are you ready for Chunky Monkey?! Sheds her coat and scarf.

dialogues.speaker: LUCY
dialogues.text: Three delis! -- as she heads into the hall to the kitchen -

dialogues.speaker: LUCY
dialogues.text: Where’s Connie?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Lucy passes the bathroom door, Connie answers from wit

dialogues.speaker: CONNIE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: I’m here.

dialogues.speaker: LUCY
dialogues.text: Time for Chunky Monkey! Lucy keeps moving on into the kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Connie takes a deep breath. Exits the bathroom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Snow falls. Connie and Jack look for a cab.

dialogues.speaker: CONNIE
dialogues.text: It’ll have to be warmer though.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Yeah. Boating weather.

dialogues.speaker: CONNIE
dialogues.text: Yeah. Jack raises his arm to hail an oncoming cab. It passes by without seeing him. They continue on towards the corner intersection.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: You sure you don’t want me to drive you?

dialogues.speaker: CONNIE
dialogues.text: No, really, it’s... It’s alright. This is plenty. I liked tonight. They walk a few moments in silence.

dialogues.speaker: CONNIE ALT
dialogues.text: Winter. Boating.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Yeah. They continue in silence. Jack observes Connie with the s falling on her. She looks at him, and he turns away shyly searches the street for a cab. He sees a cab and steps ou to stop it. The cab pulls over and he opens the door. She gets part way in and then impulsively plants an awkward k on his cheek and practically stumbles back into the cab, which takes off. Jack stands in the aftermath of the kiss kind of slam-kiss.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: INT. CLYDE AND LUCY’S APT - NIGHT 39 Clyde tastes coffee.

dialogues.speaker: CLYDE
dialogues.text: Hmmm. I'm tempted to say-- (interrupts judgment) Jack’s been gone a long time.

dialogues.speaker: LUCY
dialogues.text: Come on, five bucks you can’t tell. Buzzer.  39

dialogues.speaker: CLYDE
dialogues.text: Ha! (into intercom) Yo!

dialogues.speaker: JACK, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: (from intercom) Yo!

dialogues.speaker: CLYDE
dialogues.text: I thought maybe they ran off. (smells coffee, musing) Is it K...?

dialogues.speaker: LUCY
dialogues.text: You're supposed to taste it, and say what it is. Not stall around.

dialogues.speaker: CLYDE
dialogues.text: My nose has lost its edge. Your nose goes, your taste goes.

dialogues.speaker: LUCY
dialogues.text: It’s not the only thing.

dialogues.speaker: CLYDE
dialogues.text: What’s that mean? Jack enters. Snow on him.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: It's snowing.

dialogues.speaker: LUCY
dialogues.text: They say, a foot.

dialogues.speaker: CLYDE
dialogues.text: Took you some time.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: No cabs.

dialogues.speaker: LUCY
dialogues.text: Clyde thought maybe you went off together.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: I offered to drive but she said it'd be too much trouble. Queens, but I would have. 20 39  39

dialogues.speaker: LUCY
dialogues.text: Coffee's ready.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Maybe a cup before I go. She caught a cab to the “R” train.

dialogues.speaker: CLYDE
dialogues.text: You liked Connie?

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: We got along pretty well outside, a- hem... She said she'd like... a- hem... She'd like to go boating.

dialogues.speaker: CLYDE
dialogues.text: Boating?

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Rowing in a boat. She said, y'know, to go boating...a-hem, a- hem... sometime, when it's, hem, when... Jack drinks some water.

dialogues.speaker: CLYDE
dialogues.text: So what did you say?

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: CLYDE
dialogues.text: When she asked you to go boating.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Maybe, when it's warmer.

dialogues.speaker: CLYDE
